awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Modular Manufacturing - Democratizing Functional Materials Printing
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will research and develop new functional materials for advanced additive manufacturing. The goal of this project is to develop high performance materials for light activated 3D printers. If successful, this will enable new tools for manufacturing and research. Applications of this project would enable affordable, waste-free, and energy-efficient manufacturing with the goal of lowering barriers to innovation. Specifically, this project has the potential to improve the quality of healthcare around the world, by dramatically lowering the costs of designing and manufacturing biomedical devices.

polySpectra has developed a new class of modular 3D printing resins, capable of manufacturing production-quality parts with tailored geometry and chemical functionality in a single step. This process is called ?functional lithography,? and it unlocks the ability to simultaneously define the form and function of advanced materials. The application of functional lithography to additive manufacturing enables production-ready parts to be directly 3D-printed, whereas existing materials can only make prototypes, mock-ups or toys. The goal of this project is to develop new advanced manufacturing processes using functional lithography, towards direct additive manufacturing of high-fidelity polymer components, devices and hardware.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this SBIR Phase II award was to extend a novel photopolymerization mechanism towards applications in 3D printing. One specific application of interest was the direct additive manufacturing of biomedical devices. Under the award, polySpectra was successful in 3D printing a novel class of materials with high accuracy and isotropic mechanical properties, using off-the-shelf stereolithographic 3D printers. A wide variety of materials were explored, with applications in a number of different biomedical products, including as microfluidic devices, automotive components, and dental appliances.

The broader impacts of this award are towards accelerating innovation in hardware and physical goods. For example, using the additive manufacturing methods developed in this award, polymer components for end-use products can be directly fabricated in a few hours, without the associated cost and lead time of traditional manufacturing tooling. The Cyclic Olefin Resin (COR) materials studied in this work have dramatically improved durability over today's state-of-the art. Based on this innovation, polySpectra has grown a US-owned small business with customers across the globe, and has secured follow-on funding from venture capital investors. polySpectra successfully commercialized its COR Alpha resin and has many additional products which will be launching soon. polySpectra continues to work with its customers and partners to develop advanced additive manufacturing processes which increase supply chain resiliency, lower the carbon footprint of manufacturing, and enable the reshoring of high-tech manufacturing jobs.


Last Modified: 01/27/2022
Modified by: Raymond A Weitekamp
